The same organisers of the "Day of Anger" and "Friday of Anger" have called for a protest in front of the presidential [[Heliopolis Palace]] on 4 February, which has been dubbed the "'''Friday of Departure'''".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/163162.html|title=4 Feb. Declared the 'Friday of Departure'|author=|date=2 February 2011|work=[[Press TV]]|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> ({{lang-ar|Ø¬ÙØ¹Ø© Ø§ÙØ±Ø­ÙÙ}} ''{{transl|ar|DIN|gumÊ¿at ar-raá¸¥Ä«l}}'')<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alraimedia.com/Alrai/Article.aspx?id=253982&date=02022011|title=Ø¬ÙØ¹Ø© Ø§ÙØ±Ø­ÙÙ|language=[[Arabic language|Arabic]]|author=|date=2 February 2011|work=[[Al Rai]]|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> It is also called the ''Friday of Truth''. ({{lang|ar|Ø¬ÙØ¹Ø© Ø§ÙØ­ÙÙÙØ©}}, {{transl|ar|gumËat al-á¸¥aqÄ«qah}}).They declared that President Mubarak should step down immediately and set 4 February as the deadline for him to surrender his powers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/World-News/Egypt-Protests-What-Will-Be-The-Future-For-President-Mubarak/Article/201102115920698?lpos=World_News_First_World_News_Article_Teaser_Region_4&lid=ARTICLE_15920698_Egypt_Protests%3A_What_Will_Be_The_Future_For_President_Mubarak|title=What Is the Future for President Mubarak?|author=|date=2 February 2011|work=[[Sky News]]|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>

During the night of 3â4 February, there were tanks on the street in Cairo as anti-government protesters continued to stay overnight in Tahrir Square and pro-government protesters were also active. Many of the protesters spent the night again in Tahrir Square{{citation needed|date=February 2011}}. Small scale clashes happened in the early hours{{citation needed|date=February 2011}}.
+
During the night of 3â4 February, there were tanks on the street in Cairo as anti-government protesters continued to stay overnight in Tahrir Square and pro-government protesters were also active. Many of the protesters spent the night again in Tahrir Square<ref name="aljazlive"/>. Small scale clashes happened in the early hours<ref name="aljazlive"/>.
â
Hundreds of thousands gathered to participate in Friday day prayer in Tahrir Square<ref>http://blogs.aljazeera.net/node/3164</ref>. The day's planned events were due to start after Friday prayers.<ref name="aljazlive"/> Aljazeera estimate the crowd size to be over a million so far. <ref name="aljazlive"/>
+
Hundreds of thousands gathered to participate in Friday day prayer in Tahrir Square<ref>http://blogs.aljazeera.net/node/3164</ref>. The day's planned events were due to start after Friday prayers<ref name="aljazlive"/>. Aljazeera estimate the crowd size to be over a million so far in Tahrir Square while about half a million protest in Alexandria<ref name="aljazlive"/>. Also many protests broke in many cities all over Egypt<ref name="aljazlive"/>. The Alexandria protestØ³ have warned the government that if they used violence against protesters in Cairo, they will march to Cairo to join the protesters there<ref name="aljazlive"/>.
